steps.title: It has been estimated that one cup of strong sassafras tea could contain as much as 200 mg [milligrams] of safrole, more than four times the minimal amount believed hazardous to humans if consumed on a regular basis".
steps.content: It has been estimated that one cup of strong sassafras tea could contain as much as 200 mg [milligrams] of safrole, more than four times the minimal amount believed hazardous to humans if consumed on a regular basis". [1] X Research source Aromatic oil derived from the sassafras root bark was formerly much utilized in flavoring confections, soft drinks, and pharmaceutical products. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Such use was banned by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in 1960 after safrole was found to be hepatocarcinogenic (liver-cancer-causing) in the rat. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Find a sassafras tree.
steps.content: Find a sassafras tree. It is found in cool damp shady areas in the southern United States. It is a thin tree, usually with few limbs, and leaves that have three unequal lobes opposite the leaf stem. When the sap is down (the tree is dormant for winter), the bark and roots have a distinctive root beer odor when scraped. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Get permission from the landowner before going onto private property to search for sassafras trees.
steps.content: Get permission from the landowner before going onto private property to search for sassafras trees. Tress-passing and removing trees, or anything else from private property is a criminal offense.

steps.title: Dig or pull the tree up with its roots, remove them, and wash and cut them into 2 to 3 inch (5.1 to 7.6 cm) pieces.
steps.content: Dig or pull the tree up with its roots, remove them, and wash and cut them into 2 to 3 inch (5.1 to 7.6 cm) pieces.

steps.title: Allow them dry for a week or so.
steps.content: Allow them dry for a week or so. Keep them in a cool, dry place during the drying time to prevent them from rotting.

steps.title: Strip the bark (or skin) from the roots after they have dried, cutting it slightly into the woody part of the root.
steps.content: Strip the bark (or skin) from the roots after they have dried, cutting it slightly into the woody part of the root. The bark is where the tree stores its sap during the dormant, winter months. Store these strips of root skin in airtight containers like zipper freezer bags until ready to use.

steps.title: Boil about 2 to 4 ounces of this bark in a quart of water for twenty minutes or so and then allow it to steep until it cools.
steps.content: Boil about 2 to 4 ounces of this bark in a quart of water for twenty minutes or so and then allow it to steep until it cools. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Add the same amount of sugar you would for regular Iced Tea adjusting it to your personal tastes.
steps.content: Add the same amount of sugar you would for regular Iced Tea adjusting it to your personal tastes.

steps.title: Add more water to make it a gallon and enjoy.
steps.content: Add more water to make it a gallon and enjoy.
